Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Collaborative Research: Gulf of Mexico Oil Spill Impact on Beach Soil: Radar and Radar Sensor Network-Based Approaches

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: In response to the Gulf of Mexico oil spill innovative UWB radar sensor network imaging methodologies to produce 2-D image based on 1-D signals are under development. Using these techniques beach soil reflectivity can be measured. The differences between the reflectivity of oil spilled beach soil and that of the normal beach soil shows the dielectric property changes due to oil spill. The oil spill has changed the beach soil dispersion, and oil contamination drastically reduces the bearing capacity of sand, which impacts building foundations and may cause building safety issue. In this project, models of the relations between soil reflectivity, oil content, and compression index are under development. The research crosses multiple disciplines, including sensor networks, radars, geoscience and remote sensing, civil engineering and geotechnology, signal and image processing, wireless communications, and pattern recognition; the research team includes four investigators drawn from three departments (EE, Civil Engineering, and CSE). This project promises to generate new results for radar remote sensing and radar sensor network approaches to assessing oil spill impact on beach soil.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Gulf of Mexico oil spill in 2010 has generated deep impact on the beach soil. Microwave emission and backscattering of the beach soil depend on its dielectric property which exhibits dispersion and absorption and is affected by the oil, salt, and moisture content. Extensive studies have been performed on radars and radar sensor networks for oil spill impacts to beaches.

Intellectual Merits: 1) Ultra-WideBand (UWB) radars and radar sensor network were applied to perform the beach soil dielectric property studies due to the oil spill.  Data were collected from different beaches in New Orleans. Some beaches were contaminated by oil spill; and some beaches were clean. Oil contaminated beach is shown in Fig. 1; and radar sensor network testbed is shown in Fig. 2. Extensive data were collected on different beaches based on UWB radars. The transmit pulse of UWB radar is plotted in Fig. 3, and a received echo was plotted in Fig. 4.  The soil reflectivity kernel was obtained based on the sending pulse and received echoes for soil (Fig. 5). Based on the reflectivity kernels for the two beaches, we found that oil spilled soil has reduced the amplitude of reflectivity kernel. 2) MIMO radar was also studied to increase radar performance in detection and ranging. Orthogonal phase coded waveforms were applied to MIMO radar system in order to gain better range resolution and target direction finding performance. The concept and the design methodology for a set of ternary phase coded waveforms were proposed. MIMO radar ambiguity function of the system using phase coded waveforms was studied which shows that better range resolution could be achieved. 

Broader Impacts: The overall impact of the research that has performed in this RAPID project is broad and comprehensive. The proposed effort will provide timely response to achieving research results on oil spill impact on beach soil that would be vital to the infrastructure and people’s life in Gulf of Mexico. The RAPID project promises to generate, fundamental, revolutionary new results on radar and radar sensor network approaches for oil spill impact on beach soil and will have wide and deep scientific impact. The students working on this project gone to Gulf of Mexico beach to make measurements using UWB radar sensor networks, and the collected data and research results are available online to the public,

www.uta.edu/ee/RAPID

which will benefit this research community as well as general audience. Students in UTA EE6367 Advanced Wireless Communications, UTA EE5364 Information Theory and Coding, have used the collected data for their projects, which have enhanced their capability to handle real-world problems. Three female and minority students have been recruited for this project.
